thread.title: AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores
thread.title_full: AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores

title: AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores Arizona schools are preparing to give students and parents the first scores on the state's new Common Core standards. It might be painful. Post to Facebook AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores Arizona schools are preparing to give students and parents the first scores on the state's new Common Core standards. It might be painful.  //12ne.ws/1S05Xqj   Join the Conversation To   AZ schools prep for 1st Common Core scores Brahm Resnik , 12 News 8:17 p.m. MST October 22, 2015 Common Core test scores are in, and parents might not be happy with the results. KPNX Arizona schools prepare parents for first test results on state's new Common Core standards (Photo: Jeff Blackburn/12News) 164 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Arizona schools are preparing to give students and parents their first scores on the state's new Common Core standards over the next three weeks. 
It might be painful. 
School districts across the state got electronic access to students' results on the AZMerit test Oct. 6, and paper reports for parents were delivered to districts on Tuesday, according to Charles Tack, spokesman for School Superintendent Diane Douglas. 
The new standards have been controversial and the scores probably will be, too. Educators say the AZMerit test raises the bar, but right now they are working hard to lower students' - and parents' - expectations. 
The State Board of Education revealed in August that most Arizona students failed the AZMerit tests . Those same students were accustomed to high marks on the watered-down and now-discarded AIMS standards. 
MORE : Most Arizona students flunked AZMerit tests 
In the 2013-14 school year, for example, 62 percent of fourth graders passed the AIMS math test. This past school year, just 42 percent were either "proficient" or "highly proficient" on AZMerit. The scores get worse as grade levels rise. 
Mesa Public Schools, the largest district in the state, has embarked on a massive communications campaign to explain the scores to parents before report cards are sent home, on Nov. 16. 
The district has built a web page with information and videos in both English and Spanish. The site is being used by Mesa and smaller districts to explain the AZMerit scores to parents. 
"Districts are working together and sharing information," said Helen Hollands, spokeswoman for Mesa Public Schools. 
WATCH : Mesa Public Schools' AZMerit explainer site 
Hollands said the district was preparing for two kinds of reactions from parents whose child's score falls below AIMS levels. 
The first: "What can I do to help my child, and what are you doing to help my child?" 
The second anticipated reaction, Hollands said, is from the critics: "I told you these tests weren't any good." 
Other states that have adopted Common Core standards have seen intense blowback from parents after test scores dropped. 
The release date for individual students' test results varies across the Valley: 
-Deer Valley Unified School District plans the release between next Monday and Nov. 13. 
-Peoria schools say around Nov. 16 
-East Valley school districts have agreed on a release date of Nov. 16 
-Flagstaff Unified School District plans to send the results home before Thanksgiving break. 
For some districts, there might be a reason for the later release date. Almost 30 districts in Maricopa County are seeking approval for borrowing or budget overrides at the ballot box Nov. 3. 
Releasing the AZMerit results before then might add a new layer of controversy to those elections. 
Diane Douglas, a bitter opponent of the new standards, will release statewide, districtwide and school-level results Nov. 30 164 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://12ne.ws/1S05Xqj TOP VIDEOS
